title: Classic Clocks & Watches
description: From grandfather clocks to wind-up wristwatches, how well do you remember keeping time?

questions.question: What tall, freestanding pendulum clock, often passed down through generations, was a centerpiece of many family homes?
What type of bedside clock featured two metal bells on top and a hammer that struck them to create a loud alarm?
What brand, known for its 'Big Ben' and 'Baby Ben' alarm clocks, was a fixture on American nightstands for decades?
What Swiss watch brand used the advertising slogan 'It takes a licking and keeps on ticking' in its famous TV commercials?
What European clock, featuring a carved wooden bird that popped out to announce the hour, was a popular souvenir?
What did you have to do every day or two to keep a mechanical wind-up watch running?
What type of watch, introduced in the 1950s, used the motion of the wearer's arm to wind itself automatically?
What novelty clock, popular in diners and kitchens, featured a cat with moving eyes and a swinging tail?
What type of clock display used small numbered cards that flipped to show the time, popular in the 1960s and 1970s?
What Bulova product became the first watch advertised on American television, during a broadcast in 1941?
What type of glow-in-the-dark paint, used on watch hands and dials for decades, was later discovered to be radioactive?
What was a pocket watch chain called that looped across a man's vest from one pocket to another?
What Japanese watch company disrupted the Swiss watch industry in the 1960s with affordable, accurate quartz watches?
What type of electronic watch, displaying time in numerals rather than with hands, became a sensation in the mid-1970s?
What was the 'jewel' count on a mechanical watch movement actually referring to?
options: The quality grade of the watch
Synthetic ruby bearings that reduced friction
